questions.text: The average daily dietary nutrient intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group is known as (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Recommended dietary allowance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA)
  • ➤ Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA)
  • ➤ Definition: RDA is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population RDA is decided by a panel of experts and is based on scientific research RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement: RDA includes both daily requirement and some additional requirement for periods of growth or illness RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement RDA ‘safe level approach’ is not used for energy since excess energy intake is undesirable. For energy: only mean or average requirement is defined as RDA.
  • ➤ Definition: RDA is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population
  • ➤ RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population
  • ➤ RDA is decided by a panel of experts and is based on scientific research
  • ➤ RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement: RDA includes both daily requirement and some additional requirement for periods of growth or illness
  • ➤ RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement
  • ➤ RDA ‘safe level approach’ is not used for energy since excess energy intake is undesirable.
  • ➤ For energy: only mean or average requirement is defined as RDA.

questions.text: Silent choroid on FFA is a feature of which of the following disorders?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stargardt's disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The silent choroid or dark choroid on FFA is a distinctive feature of Stargardt's disease, caused by lipofuscin accumulation in the retinal pigment epithelium, which blocks the normal choroidal fluorescence. Recognizing this feature is crucial in diagnosing and differentiating Stargardt’s disease from other macular disorders.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and recurrent bleeding for the past 1 year. Transnasal endoscopic results are shown below. A contrast-enhanced CT revealed a mass extending from the posterior choana to the nasopharynx. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prompt and accurate diagnosis of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is critical due to its potential for significant bleeding and local invasiveness. Treatment typically involves surgical removal, with preoperative planning crucial to manage the vascular nature of the tumor effectively.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is brought to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath, cough, and hypoxia. On examination, his oxygen saturation is 84% on room air. The medical team decides to initiate oxygen therapy to improve his oxygenation status. Based on the patient's current presentation, the goal is to provide the highest concentration of oxygen available using conventional oxygen delivery methods. Which device would be the most appropriate to achieve this?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The non-rebreather mask is the best choice for delivering the highest FiO2 in conventional oxygen therapy. This mask can deliver an FiO2 of up to 80% at flow rates of 10-15 L/min. The mask includes a reservoir bag filled with oxygen and one-way valves that prevent the patient from inhaling exhaled air. This design allows the patient to breathe almost pure oxygen, which is especially useful in emergencies requiring rapid improvement of oxygenation.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A) Simple Face Mask: This mask delivers a lower FiO2 of around 60% at 10 L/min, making it insufficient for patients needing higher oxygen concentrations.
  • • Option A) Simple Face Mask:
  • • Option B) Nasal Cannula: A nasal cannula provides an FiO2 of up to 44% at 6 L/min, suitable for mild hypoxia but inadequate for severe respiratory distress.
  • • Option B) Nasal Cannula:
  • • Option D) Venturi Mask: The Venturi mask delivers an adjustable FiO2 between 24-66% depending on the flow rate and entrainment device used, offering precise oxygen delivery but not the highest concentration.
  • • Option D) Venturi Mask:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The non-rebreather mask delivers the highest FiO2 among conventional oxygen therapy devices, up to 80% at 10-15 L/min, making it ideal for situations requiring rapid oxygenation improvement in patients with severe hypoxia.

questions.text: A 70-kg patient arrives at the emergency department with acute pancreatitis and is subsequently transferred to the ICU. The patient is intubated and placed on a ventilator with the following settings: FiO₂ 90%, PEEP 12 cm H₂O, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, and tidal volume 420 ml. An arterial blood gas (ABG) reveals: pH 7.33, PaO₂ 110 mmHg, PaCO₂ 58 mmHg, and SpO₂ 100%. What would be the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Reduce FiO₂

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's oxygenation status is excellent with a PaO₂ of 110 mmHg and SpO₂ of 100% while on a high FiO₂ of 90%. Prolonged exposure to high FiO₂ levels increases the risk of oxygen toxicity and absorption atelectasis. Therefore, FiO₂ should be reduced below 60% once oxygenation is adequate. The elevated PaCO₂ (58 mmHg) with a near-normal pH (7.33) reflects compensated respiratory acidosis, which is acceptable in the context of lung-protective ventilation strategies. In ARDS, permissive hypercapnia is an accepted approach where mild-to-moderate CO₂ retention is tolerated to avoid volutrauma and barotrauma from high tidal volumes or aggressive ventilation. Thus, reducing FiO₂ is safer and more appropriate than increasing tidal volume.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Increase PEEP to 16: Not required as oxygenation is already adequate; higher PEEP may risk barotrauma.
  • • Option A. Increase PEEP to 16:
  • • Option B. Increase tidal volume: Though it may help clear CO₂, increasing tidal volume in ARDS risks volutrauma; permissive hypercapnia is preferred.
  • • Option B. Increase tidal volume:
  • • Option C. Reduce respiratory rate: Would worsen hypercapnia, which is already elevated.
  • • Option C. Reduce respiratory rate:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In ARDS, once oxygenation is adequate, FiO₂ should be reduced to ≤60% to minimize oxygen toxicity. Permissive hypercapnia is a protective ventilatory strategy that accepts mild hypercapnia to avoid ventilator-induced lung injury from high tidal volumes or pressures.

questions.text: Which of the following heart sounds would be normal in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) S3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • During pregnancy, the cardiovascular system undergoes significant changes to accommodate the increased blood volume and cardiac output required to support both the mother and the developing fetus. One of the normal physiological changes includes the presence of the S3 heart sound.
  • • S3 Heart Sound: The S3 sound, also known as the ventricular gallop, is due to rapid diastolic filling of the ventricles. It is commonly heard in pregnant women due to the increased blood volume and cardiac output.
  • • S3 Heart Sound: The S3 sound, also known as the ventricular gallop, is due to rapid diastolic filling of the ventricles. It is commonly heard in pregnant women due to the increased blood volume and cardiac output.
  • • S3 Heart Sound:
  • • Other heart sounds mentioned are not typically considered normal in pregnancy
  • • Other heart sounds mentioned are not typically considered normal in pregnancy
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. S4 Heart Sound: The S4 sound, or atrial gallop, is generally associated with pathological conditions such as left ventricular hypertrophy or myocardial ischemia. It is rare in pregnancy.
  • • Option B. S4 Heart Sound:
  • • Option C. Fixed Splitting of S2: Fixed splitting of the second heart sound is usually indicative of an atrial septal defect (ASD) and is not normal in pregnancy.
  • • Option C. Fixed Splitting of S2:
  • • Option D. Pericardial Knock: This is a sound heard in cases of constrictive pericarditis and is not a normal finding in pregnancy.
  • • Option D. Pericardial Knock:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The S3 heart sound is considered normal during pregnancy due to the increased blood volume and rapid diastolic filling of the ventricles.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 178, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 178, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following criteria corresponding to ASA grade III? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)

options.label: C
options.text: Severe illness which is constant threat to life

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Severe illness

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option D. Severe illness: The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status Classification System is used to assess and communicate a patient's pre-anesthesia medical co-morbidities. ASA grade III is defined as a patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating. This means the patient has a serious illness, but it does not necessarily pose a constant threat to life, which would correspond to ASA IV.
  • • Option
  • • D. Severe illness:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Mild illness : This corresponds to ASA II, which is defined as a patient with mild systemic disease. It does not reach the severity required for ASA III.
  • • Option A. Mild illness
  • • Option B. Moderate illness : This is not an official ASA classification term. The closest would be ASA II (mild systemic disease) or ASA III (severe systemic disease).
  • • Option B. Moderate illness
  • • Option C. Severe illness which is a constant threat to life: This corresponds to ASA IV. It describes a patient with severe systemic disease that poses a constant threat to life, not ASA III.
  • • Option C. Severe illness which is a constant threat to life:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ASA grade III corresponds to a patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating.
  • ➤ The classification system is as follows:
  • ➤ The classification system is as follows:
  • ➤ ASA I : A normal healthy patient. ASA II : A patient with mild systemic disease. ASA III : A patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating. ASA IV : A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life. ASA V : A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation. ASA VI : A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes.
  • ➤ ASA I : A normal healthy patient.
  • ➤ ASA I
  • ➤ ASA II : A patient with mild systemic disease.
  • ➤ ASA II
  • ➤ ASA III : A patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating.
  • ➤ ASA III
  • ➤ ASA IV : A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life.
  • ➤ ASA IV
  • ➤ ASA V : A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation.
  • ➤ ASA V
  • ➤ ASA VI : A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes.
  • ➤ ASA VI

questions.text: Identify the equipment shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) High flow nasal cannula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ High flow nasal cannula (HFNC) is a respiratory support system that delivers high flow rates of humidified and warmed oxygen, providing benefits such as improved oxygenation, patient comfort, and flexibility in use.
  • ➤ High flow nasal cannula (HFNC) is a respiratory support system that delivers high flow rates of humidified and warmed oxygen, providing benefits such as improved oxygenation, patient comfort, and flexibility in use.

questions.text: Which of the following elicits maximum pain on injection? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Propofol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Propofol is known to cause maximum pain on injection, often described as a severe burning sensation.

questions.text: The following are correct regarding normal placenta, except: (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Placenta weight at term is 470 g

options.label: C
options.text: Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

questions.correct_answer: C. Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The statement in option C is incorrect regarding the normal placenta.
  • • Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present: In a normal placenta, the umbilical cord typically contains three vessels (two arteries and one vein), not two. The presence of extraplacental membranes (membranes extending beyond the placental margins) is not a feature of a normal placenta; it is rather an abnormal finding if present.
  • • Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Placenta weight at term is 470 g: This is correct. The average weight of a term placenta is around 500 grams, but it can range from approximately 450 to 700 grams. The option provides a reasonable estimate.
  • • Option A. Placenta weight at term is 470 g:
  • • Option B. Round-oval with 22 cm diameter: This is partially correct. The normal placenta is indeed round to oval, but the average diameter is about 15-20 cm, not 22 cm. The provided diameter exceeds the typical range.
  • • Option B. Round-oval with 22 cm diameter:
  • • Option D. Central thickness > 2.5 cm: This is correct. The normal thickness of the placenta at term is greater than 2.5 cm, commonly around 2.5 to 4 cm. A thickness greater than 2.5 cm falls within the normal range.
  • • Option D. Central thickness > 2.5 cm:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The normal placenta at term typically weighs around 500 grams, has a diameter of 15-20 cm, is 2.5 cm thick, and has a 3-vessel umbilical cord with a central insertion.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 245 Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 245 Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A woman with 31 weeks of gestation presents with lower abdominal pain. The clinician is concerned if the patient is in preterm labor. Which of the following is the most appropriate test in this scenario? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fetal fibronectin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Fetal fibronectin (fFN) is a glycoprotein produced by fetal amnion cells and found in high concentrations in amniotic fluid. It is also found in cervico-vaginal secretions in early pregnancy (less than 22 weeks) and late pregnancy (greater than 37 weeks). The presence of fFN in cervico-vaginal secretions between 22 and 37 weeks is used as a predictor of preterm labor.
  • • A fFN level greater than 50 ng/mL is considered a significant predictor of preterm labor. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) does not recommend routine use of fFN testing but it can be helpful in specific clinical scenarios where preterm labor is suspected.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Alpha fetoprotein: Alpha fetoprotein (AFP) is used in prenatal screening for neural tube defects and as a component of the quadruple marker test for Down syndrome. Elevated AFP levels are associated with neural tube defects, while decreased levels can indicate Down syndrome.
  • • Option A. Alpha fetoprotein:
  • • Option B. Beta HCG: Beta HCG is used in early pregnancy for confirming pregnancy and in first trimester screening for Down syndrome (where levels are elevated). It is not used for diagnosing preterm labor.
  • • Option B. Beta HCG:
  • • Option D. PAPP-A: Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) is used in first trimester screening for Down syndrome, where its levels are decreased. It is not used for diagnosing preterm labor.
  • • Option D. PAPP-A:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fetal fibronectin (fFN) testing is the most appropriate test for assessing the risk of preterm labor in a woman presenting with lower abdominal pain at 31 weeks of gestation. A positive fFN test (greater than 50 ng/mL) can help predict the likelihood of preterm labor.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg 366
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg 366

questions.text: A patient presented with headache, vomiting, and fever. Meningitis was suspected. While performing a lumbar puncture, which is the last structure you will pierce just before entering the lumbar cistern? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Arachnoid mater

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The arachnoid mater is the last structure pierced before entering the lumbar cistern during a lumbar puncture.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is undergoing emergency surgery due to acute appendicitis. During intubation, the anesthesiologist uses an endotracheal tube to secure the airway. After successful intubation, the anesthesiologist explains the features of the tube, including one that provides an additional pathway for air in case of obstruction. Which feature of the endotracheal tube provides this safety mechanism?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Murphy’s eye is a key safety feature found on endotracheal tubes, located near the distal end of the tube, opposite the main lumen. This side hole serves as an alternative pathway for air to flow in case the main lumen of the tube becomes obstructed by secretions, blood, or pressure against the tracheal wall. By maintaining an airway in such situations, Murphy’s eye helps ensure continued ventilation and reduces the risk of respiratory compromise. Additionally, it minimizes the risk of tracheal mucosa injury by reducing suction effects when the main tip of the tube is occluded.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cuff : The cuff is an inflatable balloon at the distal end of the endotracheal tube that seals the airway to prevent air leakage and aspiration of secretions. While it plays a critical role in maintaining a secure airway, it does not provide an alternate pathway for ventilation like Murphy’s eye.
  • • Option A. Cuff
  • • Option C. Pilot balloon : The pilot balloon is connected to the cuff and serves as an indicator of cuff inflation. It allows the clinician to monitor and adjust the cuff pressure but does not have a role in maintaining ventilation during tube obstruction.
  • • Option C. Pilot balloon
  • • Option D. Radiopaque line : The radiopaque line is a feature embedded in the wall of the endotracheal tube, making it visible on X-rays. This line helps verify the correct placement of the tube within the airway but does not assist in ventilation or safety during obstructions.
  • • Option D. Radiopaque line

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Murphy’s eye is a safety feature found on endotracheal tubes that provides an alternative route for ventilation if the main lumen becomes obstructed, ensuring continuous airflow and reducing the risk of mucosal trauma. Understanding this feature is essential for airway management and maintaining effective ventilation during anesthesia and critical care.

questions.text: How long should elective surgery be deferred for a patient who had cough and fever, after he has recovered from COVID-19, and has not required any hospitalization?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 6 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Elective surgery should be deferred for 6 weeks in a patient who had cough and fever due to COVID-19 but did not require hospitalization. This ensures sufficient recovery time to reduce perioperative risks.
  • ➤ Elective surgery should be deferred for 6 weeks in a patient who had cough and fever due to COVID-19 but did not require hospitalization. This ensures sufficient recovery time to reduce perioperative risks.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 2423
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg
  • ➤ 2423

questions.text: Glycopyrrolate is used as a preanesthetic agent for?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reducing the secretions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Glycopyrrolate is primarily used as a preanesthetic agent to reduce secretions, thus preventing complications during anesthesia and surgery.
  • ➤ Glycopyrrolate is primarily used as a preanesthetic agent to reduce secretions, thus preventing complications during anesthesia and surgery.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 849
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 849

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient was undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Halfway through the surgery, a sudden drop in EtCO 2 to 8 mm Hg was noted. His SpO 2 became 90% and blood pressure dropped to 70/50 mmHg and peak airway pressure was 18 cm of H 2 O. What is the diagnosis? CO 2 embolism Severe bronchospasm Pneumothorax Single bronchus intubation EtCO 2 -End-tidal carbon dioxide
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 1 only

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • 1. CO2 embolism : During laparoscopic procedures, CO2 is used to insufflate the abdomen, creating a pneumoperitoneum. This allows for better visualization and manipulation of the internal structures. If there's a vascular injury, especially to a large vein, CO2 can enter the circulation and cause an embolism. This can lead to sudden cardiovascular collapse and a sharp drop in EtCO2, as observed in the scenario. Also, a sudden drop in oxygen saturation (SpO2) can occur due to the embolism obstructing the pulmonary vasculature. The significant drop in EtCO2, in this case, is indicative of a CO2 embolism.
  • • 1. CO2 embolism
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • 2. Severe bronchospasm : Bronchospasm would lead to an increase in peak airway pressure, which wasn't seen in this scenario (the peak airway pressure was 18 cm of H2O, which is within the normal range). Moreover, EtCO2 would generally be elevated in bronchospasm due to retention of CO2, not decreased as seen in the scenario.
  • • 2. Severe bronchospasm
  • • 3. Pneumothorax : A pneumothorax could cause a drop in SpO2 and blood pressure. However, the EtCO2 drop to 8 mm Hg in the setting of laparoscopic surgery more specifically suggests a CO2 embolism. Additionally, one would expect an increase in peak airway pressures with a tension pneumothorax.
  • • 3. Pneumothorax
  • • 4. Single bronchus intubation : If the endotracheal tube is advanced too far and intubates a single bronchus, it would lead to ventilation of one lung only. This can cause a decrease in SpO2, but the sudden drop in EtCO2 as seen in the scenario isn't typical for single bronchus intubation.
  • • 4. Single bronchus intubation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ A sudden and significant drop in EtCO2 during laparoscopic surgery, along with a decrease in SpO2 and blood pressure, strongly suggests a CO2 embolism.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 1879
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 1879

questions.text: β 1-3 glucan assay is used to diagnose all except? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mucormycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The β 1-3 glucan assay is not effective for diagnosing mucormycosis because the fungi causing mucormycosis (Mucor, Rhizopus) either lack (1-3)-β-D-glucan or produce it at minimal levels. This assay is useful for diagnosing fungal infections like candidiasis, aspergillosis, and Pneumocystis pneumonia which involve fungi that produce significant levels of BDG.

questions.text: Which of these is the definition of effective CPR? Respiratory rate: 20 - 24 breaths per minute. Chest compressions: 100-120/min. Allow complete chest recoil. 5-6 cm depression.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 2, 3 and 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Effective CPR includes the following components:
  • • Chest compressions: 100-120/min. This ensures that the heart is pumping enough blood to maintain circulation during cardiac arrest. Allow complete chest recoil. Allowing the chest to fully recoil between compressions ensures that the heart fills adequately with blood between each compression, which is crucial for effective circulation. 5-6 cm depression. The depth of chest compressions should be between 5-6 cm (2-2.4 inches) for adults. This depth is essential to create enough pressure to maintain circulation.
  • • Chest compressions: 100-120/min. This ensures that the heart is pumping enough blood to maintain circulation during cardiac arrest.
  • • Allow complete chest recoil. Allowing the chest to fully recoil between compressions ensures that the heart fills adequately with blood between each compression, which is crucial for effective circulation.
  • • 5-6 cm depression. The depth of chest compressions should be between 5-6 cm (2-2.4 inches) for adults. This depth is essential to create enough pressure to maintain circulation.
  • • Other Option:
  • • Other Option:
  • • Respiratory rate: 20-24 breaths per minute. This is not correct for effective CPR. The recommended respiratory rate during CPR is about 10-12 breaths per minute when an advanced airway is in place. Higher respiratory rates can lead to hyperventilation, which can be detrimental.
  • • Respiratory rate: 20-24 breaths per minute. This is not correct for effective CPR. The recommended respiratory rate during CPR is about 10-12 breaths per minute when an advanced airway is in place. Higher respiratory rates can lead to hyperventilation, which can be detrimental.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Effective CPR is characterized by chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute, allowing complete chest recoil, and compressing the chest to a depth of 5-6 cm.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 2529-2534
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg
  • ➤ 2529-2534

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus developed the following rhythm. His blood pressure was 70/40 mm Hg and he had a feeble pulse. What is the next step of management? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) DC cardioversion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and hemodynamic instability, direct current (DC) cardioversion is the recommended and most effective treatment.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 1744
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg
  • ➤ 1744

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the likely organism shown in the image below?

options.label: B
options.text: Yeast cells with Pseudohyphae are seen

options.label: D
options.text: Severe infection is seen if CD4 count is below 900

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Most commonly affects lungs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Cryptococcus neoformans most commonly affects the lungs as the primary site of infection, followed by potential dissemination to other organs, especially the central nervous system.

questions.text: Magnesium sulphate has no role in? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Prevention of seizures in severe pre-eclampsia

options.label: B
options.text: Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia

options.label: C
options.text: Prevention of RDS in premature baby

questions.correct_answer: C. Prevention of RDS in premature baby
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prevention of RDS in premature baby

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Magnesium Sulphate (MgSO4):
  • • Magnesium Sulphate (MgSO4):
  • • MgSO4 is used for several obstetric indications, including:
  • • Eclampsia: MgSO4 is the drug of choice for the prevention and treatment of seizures in eclampsia. Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia: It is used prophylactically to prevent seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia. Tocolytic in Preterm Labor: MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic agent to reduce uterine contractions and delay preterm labor. Neuroprotection in Severe Preterm Infants (<29 weeks): MgSO4 is administered to provide neuroprotection for the fetus, reducing the risk of cerebral palsy and other neurological disorders in preterm infants.
  • • Eclampsia: MgSO4 is the drug of choice for the prevention and treatment of seizures in eclampsia.
  • • Eclampsia:
  • • Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia: It is used prophylactically to prevent seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia.
  • • Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia:
  • • Tocolytic in Preterm Labor: MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic agent to reduce uterine contractions and delay preterm labor.
  • • Tocolytic in Preterm Labor:
  • • Neuroprotection in Severe Preterm Infants (<29 weeks): MgSO4 is administered to provide neuroprotection for the fetus, reducing the risk of cerebral palsy and other neurological disorders in preterm infants.
  • • Neuroprotection in Severe Preterm Infants (<29 weeks):
  • • Prevention of RDS (Respiratory Distress Syndrome) in Premature Baby:
  • • Prevention of RDS (Respiratory Distress Syndrome) in Premature Baby:
  • • MgSO4 does not play a role in the prevention of RDS. Instead, corticosteroids (such as betamethasone or dexamethasone) are used to accelerate fetal lung maturation and reduce the risk of RDS in preterm babies.
  • • MgSO4 does not play a role in the prevention of RDS. Instead, corticosteroids (such as betamethasone or dexamethasone) are used to accelerate fetal lung maturation and reduce the risk of RDS in preterm babies.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia: MgSO4 is effectively used to prevent seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia.
  • • Option A. Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia:
  • • Option B. Prevention of Recurrent Seizures in Eclampsia: MgSO4 is the preferred treatment to prevent recurrent seizures in women with eclampsia.
  • • Option B. Prevention of Recurrent Seizures in Eclampsia:
  • • Option D. Reducing Contractility of Uterus: MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic agent to reduce uterine contractility and delay preterm labor.
  • • Option D. Reducing Contractility of Uterus:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic for the removal of a small skin lesion on her forearm. The procedure is planned under local anesthesia using lidocaine. Before administering the anesthetic, the patient expresses curiosity about how the medication will prevent her from feeling pain. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of local anesthetics?

options.label: A
options.text: They increase the release of endorphins to block pain signals.

options.label: B
options.text: They inhibit calcium channels in sensory neurons, reducing neurotransmitter release.

options.label: C
options.text: They block sodium channels in nerve membranes, preventing depolarization.

options.label: D
options.text: They enhance potassium efflux from neurons, hyperpolarizing the nerve membrane.

questions.correct_answer: C. They block sodium channels in nerve membranes, preventing depolarization.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Local anesthetics, such as lidocaine, work by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels on the nerve membrane, which prevents the influx of sodium ions necessary for the depolarization of the nerve. This inhibition of sodium entry stops the propagation of action potentials along the nerve, effectively blocking the transmission of pain signals to the brain. The anesthetics have the highest affinity for sodium channels in their inactivated state, which occurs after the channels have been opened and before they return to their resting state. By stabilizing the nerve membrane and preventing conduction, local anesthetics provide effective pain relief during procedures.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) They increase the release of endorphins to block pain signals: Endorphins are natural painkillers released by the body, but local anesthetics do not function by modulating endorphin release. Their primary action is at the sodium channel level within nerve cells.
  • • Option A) They increase the release of endorphins to block pain signals:
  • • Option B) They inhibit calcium channels in sensory neurons, reducing neurotransmitter release: This mechanism is associated with certain drugs like calcium channel blockers, not local anesthetics. Local anesthetics specifically target sodium channels, not calcium channels.
  • • Option B) They inhibit calcium channels in sensory neurons, reducing neurotransmitter release:
  • • Option D) They enhance potassium efflux from neurons, hyperpolarizing the nerve membrane: Potassium channel modulation is not the primary mechanism of local anesthetics. While potassium movement does affect nerve activity, local anesthetics specifically act by blocking sodium channels to prevent depolarization.
  • • Option D) They enhance potassium efflux from neurons, hyperpolarizing the nerve membrane:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Local anesthetics block sodium channels in nerve membranes, preventing depolarization and action potential propagation, which results in the inhibition of pain sensation during medical procedures. Understanding this mechanism is crucial for appreciating how these drugs achieve their anesthetic effects.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaint of a jaw swelling. His tissue was found to have the presence of t (8;14). The histopathological appearance of the bone marrow aspirate tissue is given in the image. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Burkitt lymphoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Burkitt lymphoma is identified by the presence of the t(8;14) translocation and histopathological features including cells with cytoplasmic vacuolation and distinct nucleoli. It commonly presents with jaw or abdominal tumors and requires prompt recognition and treatment due to its aggressive nature.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with rhinitis and swelling of the face. Intranasal biopsy revealed the presence of broad-based aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching. There was evidence of vascular invasion. What will be the preferred treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Amphotericin B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treatment of Mucormycosis:
  • ➤ Treatment of Mucormycosis:
  • ➤ Mucormycosis is a serious fungal infection that requires prompt and aggressive treatment due to its rapid progression and high mortality rate. The mainstay of treatment is intravenous Amphotericin B, often followed by oral posaconazole or isavuconazole for maintenance therapy. Surgical debridement of infected tissue is frequently necessary. Controlling underlying conditions like diabetes is also crucial in managing mucormycosis.
  • ➤ Mucormycosis is a serious fungal infection that requires prompt and aggressive treatment due to its rapid progression and high mortality rate.
  • ➤ The mainstay of treatment is intravenous Amphotericin B, often followed by oral posaconazole or isavuconazole for maintenance therapy.
  • ➤ Surgical debridement of infected tissue is frequently necessary.
  • ➤ Controlling underlying conditions like diabetes is also crucial in managing mucormycosis.

questions.text: Identify the procedure done in the labor room? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cardiotocography

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows a procedure called Cardiotocography (CTG). CTG is a method used to monitor the fetal heart rate (FHR) and uterine contractions during pregnancy and labor. It helps assess the well-being of the fetus and identify any signs of fetal distress.
  • • Key points about Cardiotocography (CTG):
  • • Key points about Cardiotocography (CTG):
  • • If done antenatally (when the patient is not in labor), it is called a Non-Stress Test (NST). During labor, CTG is used to continuously monitor the fetal heart rate and contractions to ensure the fetus is not in distress.
  • • If done antenatally (when the patient is not in labor), it is called a Non-Stress Test (NST).
  • • If done antenatally (when the patient is not in labor), it is called a Non-Stress Test (NST).
  • • During labor, CTG is used to continuously monitor the fetal heart rate and contractions to ensure the fetus is not in distress.
  • • During labor, CTG is used to continuously monitor the fetal heart rate and contractions to ensure the fetus is not in distress.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Amniocentesis: Amniocentesis is an invasive procedure in which a sample of amniotic fluid is aspirated for prenatal diagnosis or therapeutic purposes. This is not the procedure shown in the image.
  • • Option A. Amniocentesis:
  • • Option B. MCA Doppler: MCA (Middle Cerebral Artery) Doppler is performed to assess fetal growth restriction and fetal anemia. It is an ultrasound procedure and does not match the image shown.
  • • Option B. MCA Doppler:
  • • Option D. Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI): AFI is an ultrasound estimation of amniotic fluid volume. It is not depicted in the image.
  • • Option D. Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cardiotocography (CTG) is used to monitor the fetal heart rate and uterine contractions during pregnancy and labor. When performed antenatally without labor, it is referred to as a Non-Stress Test (NST).

  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg339, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg122

questions.text: A 42-year-old construction worker presents to the emergency department with severe lacerations on his hand after an accident at work. The attending physician decides to perform a minor surgical procedure under local anesthesia. Despite administering the anesthetic, the patient continues to report a lingering dull ache and burning sensation, although sharper, immediate pain is reduced. The physician explains that different types of nerve fibers respond variably to anesthetics, and some are more resistant than others. Which type of nerve fiber is most likely least susceptible to the effects of local anesthetics?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Type C fibers are the least susceptible to local anesthetics due to their unmyelinated and small diameter characteristics. Local anesthetics exert their effects by blocking sodium channels, which inhibits the initiation and propagation of action potentials along nerves. Because C fibers lack myelination, they present a barrier to the anesthetic’s effectiveness, requiring higher concentrations for adequate blockade. These fibers are responsible for transmitting dull, diffuse pain and autonomic signals. The sequence of nerve fiber susceptibility to local anesthetics is B > A-delta > A-gamma > A-beta > A-alpha > C, indicating that C fibers are the most resistant. B fibers, which are highly myelinated, are the most easily blocked, whereas C fibers, being unmyelinated, stand as the least affected.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Type A-delta fibers : These fibers are thinly myelinated and transmit sharp, localized pain. Due to their myelination, A-delta fibers are more susceptible to local anesthetics than C fibers. Their small size and presence of myelin make them relatively easier targets for anesthetic action, although not as easily blocked as B fibers.
  • • Option A. Type A-delta fibers
  • • Option B. Type B fibers : B fibers are small, myelinated fibers involved in autonomic functions. They are the most susceptible to local anesthetics and are typically blocked first due to their thin myelination, allowing easy access for the anesthetic agents. Their susceptibility is the highest among nerve fibers.
  • • Option B. Type B fibers
  • • Option C. Type A-alpha fibers : A-alpha fibers are large, heavily myelinated fibers that control motor functions and proprioception. Although these fibers are relatively resistant compared to other A fibers, they are still more easily blocked than C fibers. Their substantial diameter requires higher anesthetic doses, but they are not as resistant as C fibers.
  • • Option C. Type A-alpha fibers

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type C fibers are the most resistant to local anesthetics due to their small, unmyelinated structure, requiring higher anesthetic concentrations for effective blockade. The order of nerve fiber susceptibility is B > A-delta > A-gamma > A-beta > A-alpha > C, with B fibers being the most susceptible and C fibers the least. This hierarchy is crucial in understanding why some sensations persist despite anesthetic administration.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Drug of choice to treat this condition is? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metronidazole

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge, which is a common symptom of bacterial vaginosis (BV). In bacterial vaginosis, the correct treatment is Metronidazole .
  • • Metronidazole
  • • Bacterial vaginosis is often caused by an imbalance in the normal bacterial flora of the vagina, commonly involving Gardnerella vaginalis. The condition is diagnosed using Amsel's Criteria, which include: Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge : The discharge is typically thin and white, and may have a fishy odor. pH of Vaginal fluid > 4.5 : This elevated pH level is higher than the normal acidic environment of the vagina. Fishy odor of discharge on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test) : The discharge develops a characteristic fishy odor when mixed with potassium hydroxide. Presence of Clue cells on microscopy : Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that have a stippled appearance due to adherence of bacteria.
  • • Bacterial vaginosis is often caused by an imbalance in the normal bacterial flora of the vagina, commonly involving Gardnerella vaginalis. The condition is diagnosed using Amsel's Criteria, which include: Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge : The discharge is typically thin and white, and may have a fishy odor. pH of Vaginal fluid > 4.5 : This elevated pH level is higher than the normal acidic environment of the vagina. Fishy odor of discharge on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test) : The discharge develops a characteristic fishy odor when mixed with potassium hydroxide. Presence of Clue cells on microscopy : Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that have a stippled appearance due to adherence of bacteria.
  • • Bacterial vaginosis
  • • Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge : The discharge is typically thin and white, and may have a fishy odor. pH of Vaginal fluid > 4.5 : This elevated pH level is higher than the normal acidic environment of the vagina. Fishy odor of discharge on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test) : The discharge develops a characteristic fishy odor when mixed with potassium hydroxide. Presence of Clue cells on microscopy : Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that have a stippled appearance due to adherence of bacteria.
  • • Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge : The discharge is typically thin and white, and may have a fishy odor.
  • • Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge
  • • pH of Vaginal fluid > 4.5 : This elevated pH level is higher than the normal acidic environment of the vagina.
  • • pH of Vaginal fluid > 4.5
  • • Fishy odor of discharge on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test) : The discharge develops a characteristic fishy odor when mixed with potassium hydroxide.
  • • Fishy odor of discharge on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test)
  • • Presence of Clue cells on microscopy : Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that have a stippled appearance due to adherence of bacteria.
  • • Presence of Clue cells on microscopy
  • • Metronidazole is the first-line treatment for bacterial vaginosis, and it is typically administered as oral tablets (500 mg twice daily for 7 days).
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Clindamycin : While Clindamycin can be used to treat bacterial vaginosis, it is generally not the first choice. Metronidazole is preferred due to its effectiveness and established use.
  • • Option A. Clindamycin
  • • Option C. Cotrimoxazole : This antibiotic is used for a variety of bacterial infections but is not effective for bacterial vaginosis.
  • • Option C. Cotrimoxazole
  • • Option D. Azithromycin : This is a macrolide antibiotic used primarily for sexually transmitted infections such as chlamydia and is not used for bacterial vaginosis.
  • • Option D. Azithromycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis is Metronidazole.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: A patient who receives recurrent transfusions for thalassemia develops fever and chills during this time. There is no evidence of hemolysis. Which of the following measures can decrease the rate of transfusion reactions? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:

questions.text: Which of the following is a centrally acting opioid antitussive?

While levorphanol is also an opioid with antitussive effects, it is more commonly used for pain relief. Levopropoxyphene's primary indication as an antitussive makes it the most appropriate choice among the given options.

questions.text: What is the action of the muscle at the hip, which is attached to the marked area in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Extension and lateral rotation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The primary actions of the gluteus maximus are hip extension and lateral rotation. These actions are important for movements like standing up from a sitting position, climbing stairs, and running.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A . Abduction and external rotation: The gluteus maximus does contribute to abduction but not external rotation. The primary muscles responsible for hip external rotation are the deep muscles of the hip joint.
  • • Option A
  • • Abduction and external rotation:
  • • Option C . Extension, adduction, and lateral rotation: While extension and lateral rotation are correct, adduction is not a primary action of the gluteus maximus. Adduction is more associated with the adductor muscles of the thigh.
  • • Option C
  • • Extension, adduction, and lateral rotation:
  • • Option D. Flexion and abduction: Flexion and abduction are not the primary actions of the gluteus maximus. These movements are primarily associated with other muscles like the iliopsoas for hip flexion and the tensor fasciae latae for hip abduction.
  • • Option D.
  • • Flexion and abduction:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The gluteus maximus muscle, which is attached to the gluteal tuberosity of the femur, primarily performs hip extension and lateral rotation. These actions are essential for tasks such as standing up, climbing stairs, and running. Remember, despite contributing to abduction, the gluteus maximus does not support external rotation as a primary action.

questions.text: A female patient has been receiving first-line pharmacological treatment for bipolar disorder for 6 months. This is crucial to diagnosing and managing lithium toxicity.

questions.text: Identify the incorrectly matched pair(s) of pharyngeal arch and its artery? 1st arch - Maxillary artery 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery 4th arch - Subclavian artery 6th arch - Aorta on the left side
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • All the given pairs of pharyngeal arteries and their arteries are correctly matched except for 'v' (option C).
  • • The 6th pharyngeal arch has its blood supply on the left side from the left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus, not from the aorta.
  • • Other options
  • • Other options
  • • 1st arch - Maxillary artery : Correct. The maxillary artery is indeed a derivative of the first pharyngeal arch. 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery: Correct. The hyoid artery (or the stapedial artery in its embryonic context) is derived from the second pharyngeal arch. 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery : Correct. The third pharyngeal arch gives rise to portions of the common carotid artery and the proximal part of the internal carotid artery. 4th arch - Subclavian artery: Correct on the right side. The fourth pharyngeal arch is associated with the development of the right subclavian artery and part of the aortic arch on the left side.
  • • 1st arch - Maxillary artery : Correct. The maxillary artery is indeed a derivative of the first pharyngeal arch.
  • • 1st arch - Maxillary artery
  • • 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery: Correct. The hyoid artery (or the stapedial artery in its embryonic context) is derived from the second pharyngeal arch.
  • • 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery:
  • • 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery : Correct. The third pharyngeal arch gives rise to portions of the common carotid artery and the proximal part of the internal carotid artery.
  • • 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery
  • • 4th arch - Subclavian artery: Correct on the right side. The fourth pharyngeal arch is associated with the development of the right subclavian artery and part of the aortic arch on the left side.
  • • 4th arch - Subclavian artery:

questions.text: Which of the following complication is specific to Monochorionic twins? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.correct_answer: C. Twin to twin transfusion syndrome
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Twin to twin transfusion syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Complications specific to monochorionic twins are:
  • • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) : This is a specific complication seen in monochorionic twins. There is a donor twin and a recipient twin; the donor is anemic and pale with oligohydramnios, while the recipient is polycythemic and may have circulatory overload, ascites, and hydrops. Quintero's staging is used for TTTS, and the treatment involves laser ablation of vessels. TRAP sequence (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion) : This is another specific complication seen in monochorionic twins, involving an acardiac twin.
  • • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) : This is a specific complication seen in monochorionic twins. There is a donor twin and a recipient twin; the donor is anemic and pale with oligohydramnios, while the recipient is polycythemic and may have circulatory overload, ascites, and hydrops. Quintero's staging is used for TTTS, and the treatment involves laser ablation of vessels.
  • • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)
  • • TRAP sequence (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion) : This is another specific complication seen in monochorionic twins, involving an acardiac twin.
  • • TRAP sequence (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Selective fetal growth restriction : While this can occur in monochorionic twins, it is not specific to them.
  • • Option A. Selective fetal growth restriction
  • • Option B. Polyhydramnios : This can be seen in various conditions and is not specific to monochorionic twins.
  • • Option B. Polyhydramnios
  • • Option D. Neural tube defects : These can occur in any pregnancy and are not specific to monochorionic twins.
  • • Option D. Neural tube defects
  • • Thus, options A, B, and D are not specific complications of monochorionic twins.
  • • Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg904,905
  • • Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg904,905

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of left ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Quinsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Quinsy is a severe infection requiring prompt recognition and treatment to prevent complications. It distinctly affects the peritonsillar area, leading to significant local and systemic symptoms that guide its diagnosis and management.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 299
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 299

questions.text: Which among the following options describes the chest X-ray image? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Coeur en sabot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart on a chest X-ray is characteristic of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), which results from right ventricular hypertrophy, leading to the distinctive cardiac silhouette.

questions.text: Inferior thyroid artery supply which of the following structure? 1. Thyroid 2. Parathyroid 3. Esophagus 4. Thymus
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A. 1, 2, 3 & 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk and arises from the subclavian artery. It runs upward in front of the vertebral column and enters the thyroid gland at its lower pole. Along its course, the inferior thyroid artery gives off several branches that supply the thyroid gland, parathyroid glands, larynx, trachea, esophagus, and the pharynx.
  • • Thyroid : The inferior thyroid artery primarily supplies blood to the thyroid gland . The gland requires a substantial blood supply due to its high metabolic activity, especially when it's actively producing thyroid hormones. The inferior thyroid artery enters the thyroid gland at its posterior aspect and supplies the majority of the gland, especially its inferior portion. Parathyroid : The parathyroid glands are small endocrine glands located on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland. There are usually four parathyroid glands: two superior and two inferior. The inferior parathyroid glands are typically supplied by the inferior thyroid artery. The blood supply to these glands is crucial because they produce parathyroid hormone (PTH), which plays a vital role in calcium homeostasis. Esophagus : The esophagus , especially its cervical portion, may receive some blood supply from the branches of the inferior thyroid artery. However, it's essential to note that the primary blood supply to the esophagus comes from the esophageal branches of various arteries along its length, such as the aorta and the left gastric artery. Thymus : While the inferior thyroid artery is not a primary source of blood supply for the thymus, there can be some anastomotic connections between the vessels supplying these structures in the anterior mediastinum. However, the primary blood supply to the thymus comes from the internal thoracic and anterior mediastinal branches.
  • • Thyroid : The inferior thyroid artery primarily supplies blood to the thyroid gland . The gland requires a substantial blood supply due to its high metabolic activity, especially when it's actively producing thyroid hormones. The inferior thyroid artery enters the thyroid gland at its posterior aspect and supplies the majority of the gland, especially its inferior portion.
  • • Thyroid
  • • thyroid gland
  • • Parathyroid : The parathyroid glands are small endocrine glands located on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland. There are usually four parathyroid glands: two superior and two inferior. The inferior parathyroid glands are typically supplied by the inferior thyroid artery. The blood supply to these glands is crucial because they produce parathyroid hormone (PTH), which plays a vital role in calcium homeostasis.
  • • Parathyroid
  • • inferior parathyroid glands
  • • Esophagus : The esophagus , especially its cervical portion, may receive some blood supply from the branches of the inferior thyroid artery. However, it's essential to note that the primary blood supply to the esophagus comes from the esophageal branches of various arteries along its length, such as the aorta and the left gastric artery.
  • • Esophagus
  • • esophagus
  • • Thymus : While the inferior thyroid artery is not a primary source of blood supply for the thymus, there can be some anastomotic connections between the vessels supplying these structures in the anterior mediastinum. However, the primary blood supply to the thymus comes from the internal thoracic and anterior mediastinal branches.
  • • Thymus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The thyroid gland receives its main arterial blood supply from the superior and inferior thyroid arteries. The inferior thyroid artery also supplies the parathyroid glands with blood. Additionally, its branches provide blood to the esophagus, larynx, trachea, thymus and pharynx.
  • ➤ Branches:
  • ➤ Branches:
  • ➤ Pharyngeal branches Ascending cervical artery Inferior artery Muscular branches
  • ➤ Pharyngeal branches
  • ➤ Ascending cervical artery
  • ➤ Inferior artery
  • ➤ Muscular branches
  • ➤ Thymic branches – originate from internal thoracic, inferior thyroid arteryand often superior thyroid arteries & supply the thymus.

questions.text: Which of the following variables indicates the difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and incidence among non-exposed? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Attributable risk

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Attributable risk is the metric that indicates the difference in the incidence of disease between exposed and non-exposed groups, representing the proportion of disease occurrence attributable to the exposure.

questions.text: A woman presents with dysuria and yellowish discharge. Gram staining shows gram-negative diplococci. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Neisseria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The identification of gram-negative diplococci in a patient with dysuria and yellowish discharge is highly indicative of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection, a common cause of gonorrhea

questions.text: Mental Health Gap Action (mhGAP) Program does not include: ( INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) OCD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ OCD (Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder) is not included in the WHO's Mental Health Gap Action (mhGAP) program, which focuses on other high-burden mental health conditions.

questions.text: In a study involving a population, where the mean value is 200, if the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 180-220

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Unpaired t test
